title: Set up topology for workers and RASes
content:
The network topology is the arrangement of the various elements (links, nodes, and more) in a network. Workers and RASes are part of the topology that you can configure under the TOPOLOGY tab.

The Workers tab displays information about the following items:

  • Internal RAS: an internal RAS is responsible for executing flows. The internal RAS obtains tasks (flow execution messages) to process from OO Central.

    You can assign the internal RAS to a worker group. This enables internal RAS to withstand a high action execution load and increases the availability of workers in a data center.

  • External RAS: an external RAS is a remote action server, containing a remote protocol for connecting with OO Central tenant. An external RAS will begin the connection to OO Central.

    After installing an external RAS, it will appear in the grid in the Workers tab. 

The TOPOLOGY > Workers tab displays information about each worker/RAS not restricted to the following: their status (Running or Stopped), installation path, connection details, operating system, and ID.

The status can take a minute or two to update. If you stop a RAS service, it takes a few minutes to display in the TOPOLOGY > Workers tab. There is no need to restart OO Central.

Execution Status

The TOPOLOGY > Workers tab displays information about the resources that are used by each worker/RAS, under Execution Status. This information may help troubleshoot the system and contribute to scaling and resource allocation decisions.

The information about resource consumption is automatically refreshed periodically. Note that the displayed information is only relevant to the last few minutes, since the previous refresh, and isn't cumulative. For better evaluation of your environment, it's recommended to observe the statuses over a period of time.

A worker/RAS can have one of the following execution statuses:

  • Idle: This worker has almost no tasks to process.

  • Low Utilization: This worker is working at low utilization.

    If your workers are with idle/low utilization over a long period of time, you might consider removing them.

  • Working: This worker is working with a regular load.

  • Pending on Central: Most of the time, this worker is waiting to send execution results to Central. Central is busy with handling other tasks.

    If this state displays over a long period of time, you may consider adding more OO Centrals, or monitoring your database for space, connectivity, and more, so that it doesn't become a bottleneck.

  • Loaded: At the current time, this worker works at maximum ability and isn't able to get more tasks from Central. If all your workers are loaded most of the time, consider adding more Centrals or RASes.

  • N/A: No information provided for this worker.

Worker busyness

Enable the Busyness column in the Workers tab to identify any consumed from a CPU, memory, disk, and worker threads perspective. You can then use this information to decide the usage trends of your RAS nodes for better capacity planning. The busyness level is also available via the public API so that you can fetch this data for your integrations.

Possible busyness values are Low, Medium, High, and N/A. A Low busyness value means you could give your worker more work to do. A consistently High utilization rate suggests it’s time to provide more capacity by adding more RAS nodes or increasing the CPU/memory of the worker node. 

N/A means that the busyness monitoring is disabled or that the worker is either offline/in recovery.

By default, monitoring is enabled so that you can check how busy your workers are. If you want to disable busyness monitoring, switch the worker.monitoring.disable property to True. You may want to do disable busyness reporting for your workers if this information isn't relevant to your environment and you want to avoid a possible performance overhead.

Configuration settings for busyness feature

To change the default settings for monitoring and reporting the busyness of your internal RASes, configure the following properties in the central-wrapper.conf and ras-wrapper.conf files:

Central configuration properties

  • metric.historic.sample.count - Specifies the number of historic samples to average the next incoming record. Data type: Numeric. Default value: 10.
  • Days.History.To.Keep.From.Current - Specifies the number of days for which you want to keep historical busyness records. Any older data is purged from OO_WORKER_UTILIZATION and OO_WORKR_METRIC tables.
    Data type: Numeric. Default value: 30 days.
  • global.worker.monitoring.disable - Disables worker monitoring and busyness calculation for all workers. When you disable monitoring, the Workers tab in Central UI and the API will report N/A for all workers. 
    Data type: Boolean. Default value: False

Central Worker\RAS configuration properties

  • worker.monitoring.disable: Disables monitoring for the worker. Data type Boolean. Default: False.
  • metric.collection.interval: Specifies the frequency (in seconds) of collecting metrics. Data type: Numeric. Default: 10 seconds.
  • metric.dispatch.interval: Specifies the frequency (in seconds) of sending collected metrics from workers to Central. Default: 60 seconds.

Assign an internal RAS to groups

A worker group is a logical collection of an internal RAS. Having a group, rather than a single worker, enables workers to withstand a high action execution load and increases the availability of workers in a data center.

A worker may belong to more than one group simultaneously.

Under the TOPOLOGY > Workers tab, you can assign workers to worker groups, remove workers from groups, and enable, disable, or delete workers. Some execution stages always run on the default group, which is RAS_Operator_Path. Therefore, make sure to assign at least one worker, whether internal RAS or external RAS, to this group.

It's recommended to assign most (or even all) workers to RAS_Operator_Path to optimize the execution time. You should only exclude a RAS from this group if you want to minimize its usage, and if you have only a few operations that use it.

User interface elements

TOPOLOGY > Workers

GUI item Description
Enable button

Click to enable the selected worker/RAS. The Enable button is only available if at least one disabled worker/RAS is selected.

You can't enable an internal RAS from the UI.

Disable button 

Click to disable the selected worker/RAS. The Disable button is only available if at least one enabled worker/RAS is selected.

You can't disable an internal RAS from the UI.
Delete button 

Click to delete the selected worker/RAS. The Delete button is only available if at least one worker/RAS is selected and if the selected worker/RAS isn't currently running.

You can't delete an internal RAS from the UI.
Refresh button Click to refresh the display of workers/RASes.
Clear Filters button Click to remove the filters and display all the workers/RASes.
Select Columns button Click to choose which columns to display.
Assign to Group button Click to display the Assign to Group pop-up menu.
Filter boxes In the filter boxes at the top of the columns, enter text to filter the displayed workers/RASes.
Hostname

For external RAS, it's the name of the host where this RAS is located.

For internal RAS, the Hostname becomes a link in the UI if there are multiple internal RASes within the internal RAS fleet. Click on the link to open a pop-up window that displays a full list of internal RASes in the RAS fleet.

For internal RAS, the hostname is composed of three distinct values: itom-ooras, the actual tenant ID, and the number of actual internal RASes within the fleet, in parenthesis. For example: itom-ooras-987654321 (2).
Type

Whether the item is a Central worker, a standard internal RAS, or an external RAS.

Internal RAS  : Internal RAS is responsible for executing flows. An internal worker connects to OO Central to obtain tasks (flow execution messages) to process.

External RAS  : An External RAS is a remote action server responsible for executing flows. An external worker connects to OO Central to obtain tasks (flow execution messages) to process.
Enabled Whether the internal RAS/external RAS is enabled or disabled.
Availability Whether the internal RAS/external RAS is online or offline.
Execution Status

Displays information about the resource consumption of the internal RAS/external RAS. The information about resource consumption is automatically refreshed periodically. Note that the displayed information is only relevant to the last few minutes, since the previous refresh, and isn't cumulative. For better evaluation of your environment, it's recommended to observe the statuses over a period of time.

Idle: This worker/RAS has almost no tasks to process.

Low Utilization: This worker/RAS is working at low utilization. If your workers/RASes are with idle/low utilization for a long while, consider removing them.

Working: This worker/RAS is working with a regular load.

Pending on Central: Most of the time, this worker/RAS is waiting to send execution results to Central. Central is busy with handling other tasks. Consider adding more Centrals, or monitor your database for space, connectivity, and more, to make sure it's not the bottleneck.

Loaded: At the current time, this worker/RAS isn't able to process all Central tasks. If an internal RAS/external RAS is in a loaded state for a long time, consider scaling out or scaling up by adding more worker threads.

N/A: for the internal RAS fleet it's always displayed as such. The actual status is displayed in the internal RAS fleet pop-up for each internal RAS.
Busyness

Displays the busyness state of a worker.

Displayed as N/A for internal RAS fleet. The actual status is displayed in the internal RAS fleet pop-up for each internal RAS.
OS The operating system of the machine where this internal RAS/external RAS is located.
Groups The worker groups to which the selected internal RAS/external RAS gets assigned.
Path The path to the host where this worker is located. The path indicates if the worker is in Central or in a RAS.
JDK The JDK version installed on an internal RAS/external RAS machine.
.NET The version of .NET installed on an internal RAS/external RAS machine.
ID

The unique identifier (UUID) of an internal RAS/external RAS.

UUID is a comma-separated list if there are multiple internal RASes within the internal RAS fleet. 

Topology > Workers > Internal RAS Fleet pop-up

The hostname of the internal RAS fleet is a link that allows one to view more details related to each of the internal RASes that are part of the fleet. The pop-up will display one or many available internal RASes.

If no internal RAS is available within a fleet, the internal RAS fleet isn't visible on the UI.

GUI item Description
Hostname

For internal RAS, it's a string composed out of three distinct values: itom-ooras, the actual tenant ID, and the actual RAS number within the internal RAS fleet. For example: itom-ooras-987654321-0, itom-ooras-987654321-1.
Availability Whether the internal RAS is online or offline.
Execution Status

Displays information about the resource consumption of the internal RAS/external RAS. The information about resource consumption is automatically refreshed periodically. Note that the displayed information is only relevant to the last few minutes, since the previous refresh, and isn't cumulative. For better evaluation of your environment, it's recommended to observe the statuses over a period of time.

Idle: This worker/RAS has almost no tasks to process.

Low Utilization: This worker/RAS is working at low utilization. If your workers/RASes are with idle/low utilization for a long while, consider removing them.

Working: This worker/RAS is working with a regular load.

Pending on Central: Most of the time, this worker/RAS is waiting to send execution results to Central. Central is busy with handling other tasks. Consider adding more Centrals, or monitor your database for space, connectivity, and more, to make sure it's not the bottleneck.

Loaded: At the current time, this worker/RAS isn't able to process all Central tasks. If an internal RAS/external RAS is in a loaded state for a long time, consider scaling out or scaling up by adding more worker threads.
Busyness Displays the busyness state of a worker.
ID The UUID of an internal RAS. The internal RASes of an internal RAS fleet get to have their ID preserved within restarts.

Topology > Workers > Assign to Group pop-up

GUI item Description
Assign to Group Click the button to display the Assign to Group pop-up menu.
Add New Group Select the check box and enter the name of a new group, to which the selected worker will be assigned.
<Worker groups> Select the check boxes next to group names to assign the selected worker to these groups. The display in the dialog box will vary, depending on the groups that are set up.
Apply Click to apply the changes to the worker.
Cancel Click to close the Assign to Group pop-up without saving the changes.

Assign an internal RAS/external RAS to an existing worker group

  1. Select TOPOLOGY > Workers.

  2. Select the check box next to the internal RAS/external RAS name.

  3. Click the Assign to Group button.

  4. Select the check boxes next to the worker groups that you want to assign this worker to.

  5. Click Apply.

Create a new worker group and assign an internal RAS/external RAS

  1. Select TOPOLOGY > Workers.
  2. Select the check box next to the worker name.
  3. Click the Assign to Group button.
  4. Click the check box next to the empty box and enter the name of the New Worker Group that you want to create.
  5. Click Apply.

Remove an external RAS from a worker group

  1. Select TOPOLOGY > Workers.
  2. Select the check box next to the worker name.
  3. Click the Assign to Group button.
  4. Clear the check boxes next to the worker groups that you want to remove this worker from.
  5. Click Apply.

Disable a worker/RAS

For internal RAS

You can't disable an internal RAS from the UI. 

You can only reconfigure an internal RAS when you configure RAS fleet. For details on configuring RAS fleet, see Configure internal RAS fleet. 

For external RAS

  1. Select Content Management > TOPOLOGY > Workers.
  2. Select the check box next to the worker name.
  3. In the Workers toolbar, click Disable  . The Disable button is only available if at least one enabled worker is selected.

Enable a worker/RAS

For internal RAS

You can't enable an internal RAS from the UI. 

You can only reconfigure an internal RAS when you configure RAS fleet. For details on configuring RAS fleet, see Configure internal RAS fleet. 

For external RAS

  1. Select TOPOLOGY > Workers.
  2. Select the check box next to the name of the disabled worker.
  3. In the Workers toolbar, click Enable . The Enable button is only available if at least one disabled worker is selected.

Delete a RAS

For internal RAS

You can't delete an internal RAS from the UI. 

You can only reconfigure an internal RAS when you configure RAS fleet. For details on configuring RAS fleet, see Configure internal RAS fleet. 

For external RAS

You can delete an external RAS from TOPOLOGY > Workers tab only if it's stopped.

If you have stopped an external RAS service (or even uninstalled the RAS), it takes a few minutes until this is reflected in the TOPOLOGY > Workers tab. You may need to wait for a few minutes before that status is updated to Stopped, before you can delete the RAS. There is no need to restart Central.

  1. Select TOPOLOGY > Workers.
  2. Select the check box next to the worker's name.
  3. In the Workers toolbar, click Delete  .
  4. Note The Delete button is only available if at least one worker is selected and if the selected worker isn't currently running.

Verify the RAS installation

You can use the TOPOLOGY > Workers tab to verify that an external RAS component was successfully installed.

If a worker is successfully installed, it will be visible in the grid and shown to be online and its Availability column will display Online.

  • If a new component for Central was installed successfully it will appear on the screen. If there is no addition on the TOPOLOGY > Workers tab after the component was installed, this means that there was a problem and you should inspect the logs.

  • The TOPOLOGY > Workers tab displays the status of the worker, so you can see if the new component is viable.

    For example, the status will be red (unusable) if there are problems with certificates, failures in the operation of the worker unrelated to the initial installation, or loss of network connectivity with the component.

  • All workers display their Hostname in the TOPOLOGY > Workers section. You can identify an internal RAS from an external RAS by its unique hostname as in itom-ooras-<TENAND_ID>-0

Related topics

For instructions to install an external RAS in an on-premises environment, see Install an external OO RAS.
